issues.description: Interface naming mismatch: the problem statement and UML describe a 'Milkable' interface (with method messageOnMilk()) and the template/Main references Milkable, but the solution implementation introduces an interface named 'Dairy' and has classes (Goat, Seal) implement Dairy instead of Milkable. This divergence in type names is structural (a different interface/type) and will confuse students about which interface to implement and use, and will break any tests or starter code expecting Milkable.
issues.suggested_fix: Use a single consistent interface name across all artifacts. Rename the solution's 'Dairy' interface to 'Milkable' (or make 'Milkable' an alias/interface implemented by the classes) and update Goat and Seal to implement Milkable. Ensure the interface declares messageOnMilk() as specified in the problem statement so template code and tests referring to Milkable compile and work as intended.

issues.description: Empty/placeholder Milkable.java present in the solution repository: there is a Milkable.java file in the solution repository that appears to have no content while the solution actually defines a 'Dairy' interface. The presence of an empty Milkable.java alongside Dairy.java creates confusion about which interface is authoritative and may mislead students or cause compilation issues if inconsistent types are expected.
issues.suggested_fix: Remove the empty Milkable.java or implement it properly in the solution repository. Preferably, unify by providing only 'Milkable.java' (with messageOnMilk()) and remove 'Dairy.java', or implement Milkable and have all classes implement it. This removes ambiguity and aligns the solution with the problem statement and template expectations.

issues.description: The problem statement and the template refer to the milking capability/interface as 'Milkable' (UML and template Main use Milkable), but the solution implementation defines and uses an interface named 'Dairy' (Dairy.java) and has Goat and Seal implement Dairy. Additionally, a Milkable.java file in the solution repository is empty. This means the same conceptual entity (the interface representing 'can be milked') is referenced with two different identifiers across artifacts, which will confuse students trying to map the requirement (implement Milkable) to the provided solution code (which uses Dairy).
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the interface name across all artifacts. Rename the solution's Dairy interface to Milkable (and update its filename to Milkable.java) and have Goat and Seal implement Milkable. Remove the empty Milkable.java file (or replace it with the renamed interface). Alternatively, if 'Dairy' is preferred, update the problem statement and template to use 'Dairy' instead of 'Milkable'—but prefer aligning the solution to the problem/template (i.e., use 'Milkable') so students can directly map requirements to the provided code.
